Award.AwardTitle: New REU Site: REU Program in Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&M University-Commerce
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is to support a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates site at Texas A&M University-Commerce. The site will recruit primarily from 2 year community colleges across the nation. This model addresses a national need, especially in rural areas, to support community college STEM majors as they make transitions to universities to complete their bachelor's degree in physical sciences. During ten weeks each summer, ten REU students will engage in active research with TAMU-C research teams led by faculty members and may include research scientists, postdocs, graduate and senior undergraduate students resulting in publications in professional journals/meetings in physics and astronomy. Projects will be available in five areas: Astronomy and Astrophysics, Nuclear and Particle Physics, Material Sciences, Computational and Mathematical Physics, and Engineering and Applied Physics. This award is co-funded by the Division of Physics and the Division of Astronomical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) program supported 23 students selected nationally from 2-year community colleges to participate in cutting edge research projects led by faculty members in Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&M University-Commerce. We aimed at establishing a successful model to address the tremendous national need, especially in rural areas, of supporting community college students as they make transitions to 4-year universities to complete their bachelor’s degree in physical science and go on to graduate studies.  Early involvement in research starting from the freshman year has been shown to be one of the most effective ways of attracting talented undergraduates to, and retaining them in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) careers. However, students in 2-year community colleges, especially minority students in the economically underdeveloped areas often do not have the same opportunity to engage in meaningful research experiences as those who begin their postsecondary education in 4-year universities. Community colleges are becoming the primary access point to higher education for those who have been traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, such as minority, first-generation, nontraditional, and low-income students.

All 23 participants of our REU program have successfully transferred to 4-year colleges and some of them have already entered into top graduate schools. The REU students gained their very first hands-on experience in research and are strongly motivated to become next generation scientists and engineers.
